channel.title: BBC News - Business

item.title: Twitter: Elon Musk blames 'activist groups' for earnings drop
item.description: Elon Musk, the new owner of Twitter, makes the accusation as the tech firm makes sweeping job cuts.

item.title: Will falling gas prices mean lower bills?
item.description: Higher demand in winter could push up the wholesale gas price before households feel much benefit.

item.title: US jobs growth solid but slowing amid inflation fight
item.description: The news comes as the economy remains a top concern for voters ahead of the midterm elections.

item.title: Twitter staff say layoffs have started after Elon Musk takeover
item.description: Employees are saying on social media they have lost their jobs ahead of an announcement by the company.

item.title: Workers at Heathrow to strike in World Cup run-up
item.description: A union says 700 workers at the UK's biggest airport will walk out for three days from 18 November.

item.title: Scholz asks China to press Russia to end its war
item.description: The German leader uses a controversial trip to urge Beijing to persuade Russia to halt its invasion.

item.title: New UK nuclear plant under review
item.description: A government official had told the BBC that every major project was under review.

item.title: Glencore ordered to pay millions over Africa oil bribes
item.description: A court heard a subsidiary of mining firm Glencore bribed officials with cash flown in on private jets.

item.title: Will people sign up for Netflix's cheaper ad service?
item.description: The streaming platform has launched a less expensive streaming option with commercials.

item.title: Bank of England: Five things we now know about the UK economy
item.description: The Bank of England's outlook for the UK is grim, but some things might not be as bad as first expected.

item.title: TikTok says staff in China can access UK and EU user data
item.description: The Chinese-owned platform said the policy is "based on a demonstrated need to do their job".

item.title: Twitter to lose magic with blue tick fee, former exec says
item.description: Twitter's former global communications head tells BBC News he is worried about Elon Musk's plans.

item.title: The Fed hikes US interest rates to fresh 14-year high
item.description: The Federal Reserve is steering borrowing costs higher at the fastest rate in decades.

item.title: China Covid: Panic and fear drove iPhone factory breakout
item.description: Workers at the plant in Zhengzhou, China, thought they were going to be part of a huge Covid experiment.

item.title: CVS and Walgreens agree to pay $10bn to settle opioids lawsuits
item.description: Local governments and others who had brought more than 3,000 lawsuits must now decide whether to accept the deals.

item.title: China Covid: Area around world's biggest iPhone plant locked down
item.description: The move may have an impact on production of the new iPhone 14, which is made at Foxconn's factory.

item.title: Tinder: More pay for dating app despite cost-of-living crisis
item.description: The number of paid subscriptions to the dating app rose sharply in July to September.

item.title: Bank of England expects UK to fall into longest ever recession
item.description: The Bank of England raises interest rates to 3%, marking the biggest rise for 33 years.

item.title: CEO Secrets: Sarah Willingham on impostor syndrome
item.description: Sarah Willingham, CEO of Nightcap and former star of TV show Dragons' Den, shares her CEO Secret.

item.title: How solar farms in space might beam electricity to Earth
item.description: The UK government is supporting projects to put solar panels in space and beam energy back to Earth.

item.title: Your next job interview could take place in virtual reality
item.description: Job interviews can now take place in VR worlds with a computer asking the questions.

item.title: Why lasers are being used to write inside diamonds
item.description: A British company is using unique technology to inscribe diamonds with sophisticated lasers.

item.title: Telangana’s ambitious palm oil strategy to help India reduce import
item.description: The Telangana state government is investing heavily in the crop, but experts remain sceptical.

item.title: New York cleaners create new path to entrepreneurship
item.description: Can taking a trick from McDonald's help make co-operatives more efficient?

item.title: Crunch time as potato chip firms adopt plastic-free packets
item.description: While the big producers ask for more time, smaller businesses are going biodegradable.

item.title: California's cannabis-growing nuns pray for profits
item.description: The income the Sisters of the Valley make from growing cannabis is at half its pre-pandemic level.

item.title: CEO Secrets: 'Don't wait for a viral moment'
item.description: Ben Lebus, CEO of cooking platform Mob, shares why going viral might not be the best for business.

item.title: The ships full of gas waiting off Europe’s coast
item.description: In the middle of an energy crisis, giant ships full of liquefied natural gas are waiting off Europe's coast.

item.title: Meet the designers with learning disabilities
item.description: A design agency in Barcelona has creatives with learning disabilities, autism and schizophrenia.

item.title: Why inflation is so high - and your other questions answered
item.description: The BBC's economics editor Faisal Islam answers your questions on inflation.

item.title: Zimbabwe: Australian firm drills for oil and gas
item.description: Zimbabwe's first gas production could be led by a new well being drilled in the north of the country.

item.title: 'I turned my front room into a full-time bakery'
item.description: Ben Gray explains why he turned his home into a bakery in lockdown.

item.title: Cost of living: 'A lot of people have nowhere to turn'
item.description: Inflation could rise to 13% and the cost of living is putting a squeeze on finances, so how are people feeling?
